BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Little snow will fall until Thursday.
Especially above approximately 2000 m: Near the border with France and along the border with Switzerland 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall. The moderate wind will transport the new snow. In these regions and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a crust especially on sunny slopes. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular steep south, west and southeast facing slopes: The new snow will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
Below approximately 2200 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some new snow: The danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Individual gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.

At elevated altitudes small wind slabs will form. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. Individual wet loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in some regions, in particular in the north. The moderate wind will transport only a little snow. The snowpack is largely stable.
Intermediate and high altitudes: The old snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday. Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
The mostly small wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack. Towards its surface, the snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
Over a wide area only a little snow is lying on south facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will hardly soften at all. The various wind slabs have bonded well with each other and the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night was good. Wind slabs above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. The hard wind slabs of recent weeks can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 3000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Old wind slabs in particular adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects. Distinct weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in isolated cases even by individual winter sport participants in particular on steep shady slopes. This applies in particular in little used terrain, as well as in areas where the snow cover is rather shallow above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. It is advisable to bring a snow knife and crampon with you for the steeper sections.
Avalanches can be released in the old snowpack in very isolated cases. This applies in particular in case of a large load. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Individual weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes and sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust will soften later than the day before.
In all regions as well as in all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland a little new snow above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area a lot of new snow to below approximately 1400 m. The avalanche danger will increase significantly during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. Individual moist avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be in most cases stable. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 20 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will hardly soften at all. It is advisable to bring a snow knife and crampon with you for the steeper sections.
As the temperature drops hardly any more natural avalanches are possible.
Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be generally stable.
In the Prealps as well as at low altitude no snow is lying. Also in neighbouring regions less snow than usual is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area a lot of new snow to below approximately 1500 m. The avalanche danger will increase significantly during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low avalanche danger will prevail. The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
At elevated altitudes small wind slabs will form. Somewhat older wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. Individual moist and wet avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in some localities, in particular in the north. The moderate wind will transport only a little snow. The snowpack will be in most cases stable.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate and high altitudes: The old snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the snowpack in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday. Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some regions a little new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Little snow will fall until Thursday in some localities. Especially above approximately 2000 m: In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 2 (moderate) 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall.
The moderate wind will transport the new snow.
The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a crust especially on sunny slopes. The small wind slabs can be released in some cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Small dry and moist avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
The greatest danger remains that of slipping on hard snow. We recommend bringing snow knives and crampons with you for the steeper sections.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Low and intermediate altitudes and sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like.
In particular steep south, west and southeast facing slopes: Towards its surface, the snowpack is hard and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
Below approximately 2200 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some new snow: The danger will increase during the day.
